io.zbox.zboxfs

Class VersionReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.zbox.zboxfs.VersionReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public class VersionReader
extends Object
    A reader for a specific version of file content.

    This reader can be obtained by File.versionReader(long) method and must be closed after use.

    A typical usage pattern is:

    1. Get file history versions using File.history()
    2. Get a version reader for a specific version number using File.versionReader(long)
    3. Read content using read(ByteBuffer) or readAll()
    4. Close the version reader using close()

    Example

     // get file history versions
 Version[] hist = file.history();

 // suppose the history version list is:
 // [
 //   { num: 42, contentLen: 123, createdAt: 1540376682 },
 //   { num: 43, contentLen: 456, createdAt: 1540376683 }
 // ]
 // then we can choose version 42 to read from and creating a version reader from it
 VersionReader vr = file.versionReader(42);

 // read all content from this version
 ByteBuffer buf = vr.readAll();

 // close version reader
 vr.close();
    See Also:
    File

    • Method Detail

      • read

        public long read(ByteBuffer dst)
          throws ZboxException
        Pull some bytes from this version reader into the specified buffer, returning how many bytes were read.

        The bytes are appended to the destination buffer dst. That is, the writing starts from the current position in dst.

        It is recommended to use a direct ByteBuffer to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the byte buffer into which bytes are to be written
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        readAll()

      • read

        public int read(byte[] dst,
                int off,
                int len)
         throws ZboxException
        Pull some bytes from this version reader into the specified byte array, returning how many bytes were read.

        This method copies n bytes from this version reader into the given destination array. If there is no exception thrown, then it must be guaranteed that 0 <= n <= len.

        It is recommended to make len less than 16KB (16384) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the array into which bytes are to be written
        off - the offset within the array of the first byte to be written; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length
        len - the maximum number of bytes to be written to the given array; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length - offset
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • read

        public int read(byte[] dst)
         throws ZboxException
        Pull some bytes from this version reader into the specified byte array, returning how many bytes were read.

        This method copies bytes from this version reader into the given destination array. An invocation of this method of the form file.read(dst) behaves in exactly the same way as the invocation

         vr.read(dst, 0, dst.length)

        It is recommended to make dst.length less than 16KB (16384) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the array into which bytes are to be written
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • readAll

        public ByteBuffer readAll()
                   throws ZboxException
        Read all bytes until end of the version reader, placing them into the returned buffer.
        Returns:
        the byte buffer holds all read bytes
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        read(ByteBuffer)

      • seek

        public long seek(long off,
                 SeekFrom whence)
          throws ZboxException
        Seek to an offset, relative to from in bytes, in this version reader.

        This method returns the new position from the start of the content. That position can be used later with SeekFrom.START.

        A seek beyond the end of the file is allowed. In this case, subsequent write will extend the file and have all of the intermediate data filled in with 0s.

        Parameters:
        off - the offset within this file, relative to whence
        whence - the start point to calculate seek offset
        Returns:
        new position from the start of the content
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        SeekFrom

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes this instance and releases any resources associated with this instance.
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
